meson: add option to disable pam tests

note.body:
Thanks for the reply @flk, yeah make sense. If Niels thinks this is a good idea, I'm happy to take another look.

cc @nielsdg

target_title: meson: add option to disable pam tests

note.body:
Sorry. I hadn't read this issue yet. I can't add anything to @pachoramos1 's arguments. Of course, from the distributor's point of view, it's nice if you can avoid permanent patching. But I also understand @nielsdg 's argument from the developer's point of view. 

I use openembedded and it also builds from source. It is a cross-compile environment and building the libsecret pam tests was not straight forward. So my first idea was also to simply patch out the tests. But I was asked to suggest an option upstream to avoid a patch. So I sent the PR.

target_title: meson: add option to disable pam tests

note.body: Thanks for the PR. But, I'm [not sure](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libsecret/-/issues/96#note_2278090) why we need this change.

target_title: meson: add option to disable pam tests

secret-service: guard against NULL paths in secret_service_signal

note.body:
> Is `g_return_if_fail()` appropriate here?

Yes.

And yes, you're correct about the `G_DISABLE_CHECKS`. But, it's very commonly found in GNOME code bases. In libsecret we use it to check references and return from void functions.

target_title: secret-service: guard against NULL paths in secret_service_signal

note.body:
Is `g_return_if_fail()` appropriate here? It's supposed to be used to check arguments to public APIs according to the docs and `secret_service_signal()` is not public.

More worryingly `g_return_if_fail()` disappears if `G_DISABLE_CHECKS` is defined. I don't think this check should be possible to remove.

target_title: secret-service: guard against NULL paths in secret_service_signal

note.body: Right, there we go. Thanks for taking care of that.

target_title: Direct self-inclusion of header file 'secret-item.h'

note.body: Good catch, thanks @dilyan.palauzov

target_title: Direct self-inclusion of header file 'secret-item.h'

pam/meson.build: pam tests dependencies are always required

note.body: Well, in Gentoo (or other distributions building from the sources) it is a bit more complicated because most regular users won't need to run the tests (as the developers will do), even if they will still compile libsecret. We can try to skip it downstream... but I preferred to contact upstream before to avoid us from needing to patch it forever

target_title: pam/meson.build: pam tests dependencies are always required

note.body:
I don't think we want to disable tests really in any case; _if_ something got screwed up because some flag did or didn't get set, we (or the distribution building) should know at compile time, not later.

Is there a specific reason to not have pam_wrapper? It's also only a build dependency. If it's a distro-specific thing to not have pam_wrapper, wouldn't it be possible to just patch this out in any case?

target_title: pam/meson.build: pam tests dependencies are always required

note.body:
Yeah of course, I'll look into it. But this might take some time. Because, this is not an urgent issue to fix.

Thanks!

target_title: pam/meson.build: pam tests dependencies are always required
pam/meson.build: pam tests dependencies are always required

note.body:
Would it be possible to change
```
pam_wrapper = dependency('pam_wrapper', required: true)
libpamtest = dependency('libpamtest', required: true)
```

From true to false? I saw a similar approach for example in:
https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/libfprint/fprintd/-/commit/ff0aa64e2d9e72d8b54b28cd3615ee3cfe342fdc

Another option could be to move the tests part of pam/meson.build under "if get_option('tests')", and have a tests option to configure their building and running

target_title: pam/meson.build: pam tests dependencies are always required
pam/meson.build: pam tests dependencies are always required

note.body: No worries, thanks!

target_title: pam/meson.build: pam tests dependencies are always required

note.body:
Sorry, I got confused with another package that was having a "test" option to skip the building of them (when they are not going to be run), but I have just rechecked and it seems that libsecret always builds them (even if they won't be used). Maybe it would be interesting to allow to disable them (to also skip the extra dependencies)

Thanks a lot

target_title: pam/meson.build: pam tests dependencies are always required

note.body:
Hi @pachoramos1 

What do you mean by "trying to build with tests disabled"?

target_title: pam/meson.build: pam tests dependencies are always required
Possible Memory Leaks on nearly every call

note.body: It would be great if this Issue gets the Not Actionable Label removed. I think we established, that this Label might not be correct. This could discourage other Maintainers commenting/ looking at this Issue.

target_title: Possible Memory Leaks on nearly every call

note.body:
Hello, I've been also experiencing some possible memory leaks even when just using `secret-tool`.

```sh
valgrind --leak-check=full --suppressions=/home/sentience/Downloads/glib.supp --num-callers=20 secret-tool store --label='some' atr val
```

